revisions.rev:
{{Infobox company| company_name = Napster, Inc. | company_logo = [[Image:Napster corporate logo.svg|220px]] | company_type = [[Subsidiary]] | parent = [[Best Buy]] | foundation = [[1999]] as free (and reconfigured as non-free by Roxio in [[2003]]) | location = [[Los Angeles, California]], [[USA]]| key_people = Christopher Allen, [[General Manager]][[Napster]]: ''[http://www.napster.com/management.html Napster Management].| num_employees = 138 ([[2007]])| industry = Online Music| products = Napster
Napster to Go
Napster MP3 Store| revenue = {{profit}}$111.08 million [[United States dollar|USD]] (FY 2007)| net_income = {{loss}}$36.83 million [[United States dollar|USD]] (FY 2007)| homepage = [http://www.napster.com/ www.napster.com]| }} '''Napster''' is an [[online music store]] and a [[Best Buy]] company. It was originally founded as a file sharing service. For more information about its founding mission as a free [[file sharing]] service, see [[Napster]]. ==History== {{Infobox software |name = Napster |screenshot = |caption = Napster 4.6.2.8 |developer = [http://www.napster.com/about_napster.html Napster, Inc.] |latest_release_version = 4.6 |latest_release_date = September 2010 |operating_system =[[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Linux]] |genre = [[media player (application software)|Media player]] |license = [[Digital rights management|DRM]]-free [[MP3]], [[Windows Media Audio|WMA]] |website = [http://www.napster.com/ Napster.com] }} The company's name and logo originated from bankruptcy liquidation of the [[Napster]] [[peer-to-peer]] file trading service,{{cite news | title=Porno company offers to buy Napster | date=September 12, 2002 | publisher=CNET News.com | url=http://news.com.com/2100-1023-957784.html?tag=fd_top}} which was shut down after a series of legal actions taken by the [[RIAA]]. The brand name was later purchased by [[Roxio]], to capitalize on the popularity of the former service. Napster was later acquired by [[Best Buy]]. ===As a Roxio subsidiary=== Roxio bought the assets of the original [[Napster]] company at its [[bankruptcy]] [[auction]] in [[2002]] and the online music service called [[pressplay]] in [[2003]], with the intention of using these assets as the basis of a new legal online music service which would let users access music through a subscription or on a fee-per-song basis. Roxio spent years revamping the company as a non-free online music service. This involved a great deal of management re-organization and the start of a new business model. Roxio spent years developing a network of business partners and relationships to ensure success for their new enterprise.{{note|penn}}[http://live.psu.edu/story/4586 Penn State and Napster team up to make legal tunes available to students]{{note|Security}}[http://www.engadget.com/2006/08/25/fairuse4wm-strips-windows-media-drm/ FairUse4WM strips Windows Media DRM!]{{note|Security2}}[http://www.connectedhomemag.com/Articles/Print.cfm?ArticleID=45489&Path=HomeOffice /How To Steal Music..... Sort Of]{{note|Security3}}[http://www.zunta.org/blog/archives/2005/02/17/digital_audio_e/index.php/Digital Audio extravaganza!]{{note|advert}}[http://www.slyck.com/misc/napster_math.jpg Do the Math advertisement]{{note|TMO}}[http://www.macobserver.com/article/2005/02/03.2.shtml TMO reports]{{note|subscribers}}As of January 18, 2006. See [http://investor.napster.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=184617&Version=US press release]{{note|rhapsody}}[http://www.realnetworks.com/company/press/releases/2006/q405results_8r16Js.html As of the 2006 fiscal year], the last year Real broke out dedicated Rhapsody subscriber numbers.{{note|revolt}} {{cite news | last=Vance | first=Ashlee | title= Penn State students revolt against Napster, DRM invasion | date=November 7, 2003 | publisher=The Register | url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2003/11/07/penn_state_students_revolt_against/}} {{note|uni}} Napster, Inc (July 19, 2004). [http://www.napster.com/press_releases/pr_040719.html Global Napster Expands University Program with the Addition of Six Schools]. Press Release.{{note|layoffs}}{{cite news | last=Viega | first=Alex | title= Napster denies rumors of trouble amid layoffs | date=January 25, 2006 | publisher=San Jose Mercury News | url=http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/news/local/states/california/northern_california/13711562.htm }}{{note|acquisition}} {{cite news | last=White | first=Michael | title=Napster Hires UBS to Evaluate Possible Company Sale | date=September 18, 2006 | publisher=Bloomberg | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=a9tR36Po_wRU}}{{note|acquisition2}} {{cite news | last=Hessaldahl | first=Arik | title=A Needy Napster Searches for Takers | date=September 19, 2006 | publisher=Business Week | url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/sep2006/tc20060919_053475.htm}} In May 2006, Napster launched Free Napster (via the URL http://Free.Napster.com/) but this service was discontinued in March 2010. It was a free, advertising-supported Web experience which enabled music fans in the USA to stream full-length versions of all the songs in Napster's catalog of over 8 million tracks three times each, without downloading any software or making any service commitment. Visitors could also purchase DRM-free MP3 downloads. ===As a Best Buy company=== Napster was formerly headed by [[Chris Gorog]] who served as Chairman and CEO, Bradford D. Duea who served as President and Christopher Allen who served as Chief Operating Officer. On January 6, 2010, Gorog and Duea stepped down from their positions. In an interview, Gorog stated that "After we understood the approach Best Buy was taking with Napster, it became clear the company didn't need a CEO, a president and a COO going forward".[http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/e3ieea0d35bc59ea6b955f8b74ce7b0cfbe Q&A: Napster ex-CEO Chris Gorog] by Antony Bruno, January 19, 2010 Allen assumed the position of "General Manager," reporting to Chris Homeister, Best Buy's senior vice president of merchandising entertainment.[http://digitaldaily.allthingsd.com/20100106/former-napster-ceo%E2%80%99s-dream-more-of-a-nightmare-when-you-really-think-about-it/ Former Napster CEOâs âDreamâ More of a Nightmare When You Really Think About It] by John Paczkowski, January 6, 2010{{note|acquisition3}} {{cite news | first=Larry | last=Dignan | date=September 15, 2008 | title=Best Buy acquires Napster; Eyes digital music distribution | url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/BTL/?p=10026}} == Services == '''Napster''', the basic subscription tier, offers unlimited listening for $5â7 per month (Â£5 per month in the UK). USA members may also purchase DRM-free MP3 downloads at a discount. Napster also offers an MP3 store, a pay-per-track store which does not require a monthly subscription fee. '''''Napster Premium''''', the company's portable subscription tier, allows unlimited transfer of music for $8-10 per month (Â£8 per month in the UK) Users may transfer to their choice of [[PlaysForSure]]-compatible [[digital audio player]]s, cell phones and [[Personal digital assistant|PDAs]] in addition to unlimited [[Streaming media|streaming]]. Members may also purchase DRM-free MP3 downloads at a discount. Napster's mobile music service '''Napster Mobile''' enables users to search and browse Napsterâs music catalog and preview, purchase and play songs on their mobile handset through an integrated music player. ==See also== *[[Windows Media Player]] *[[Streaming media]] *[[Digital Rights Management|DRM]] *[[Online music store]] *[[MusicStation]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.napster.com Official website] {{Digital Distribution Platforms}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Napster (Pay Service)}} [[Category:Streaming music services]] [[Category:Online music stores]] [[Category:Windows software]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2003]] [[Category:Companies based in Los Angeles, California]] [[Category:2011 disestablishments]] [[de:Napster (Online-Musikdienst)]] [[it:Napster (servizio a pagamento)]]
